project.name: Data Structure Visualizer
project.description: CodePen-like application for visualizing data structures with real-time animated visualization. 100% client-side, no backend.

metadata.methodology: Ralph Wiggum - Autonomous AI Agent Development

userStories.title: Binary Tree Template Registration Mismatch - EditorPanel Crash
userStories.description: The Binary Tree templates are registered with identifier 'binarytree' but the DataStructureType uses 'tree', causing complete page crash. EditorPanel component throws error and page displays blank. Console shows: 'An error occurred in the <EditorPanel> component'.
userStories.actualBehavior: Navigating to http://localhost:5173/?ds=tree&difficulty=easy results in completely blank page. Console shows EditorPanel component error. No UI elements render.
userStories.expectedBehavior: Binary Tree page loads successfully with skeleton code in editor and test cases visible.
acceptanceCriteria: Binary Tree templates are registered with identifier 'tree' (not 'binarytree')
Navigating to ?ds=tree loads without errors
EditorPanel renders successfully with skeleton code
No console errors when Binary Tree is selected
All three difficulty levels (easy, medium, hard) load correctly for Binary Tree
Visualization panel displays tree structure placeholder
Test cases panel shows Binary Tree test cases

verify.expected: No EditorPanel errors, no template registration errors
Editor, test cases, and visualization panels all visible

technicalDetails.rootCause: Template registration uses 'binarytree' identifier but DataStructureType enum uses 'tree'
technicalDetails.fix: Change registration calls from registerTemplate('binarytree', ...) to registerTemplate('tree', ...)

userStories.title: Loop Counter Variable Scoping Error in Code Instrumentation
userStories.description: When instrumenting user code with loop counters for infinite loop detection, the __loopCount_N variables are not properly scoped. This causes 'is not defined' errors when running reference solutions with loops. Affects Stack (Balanced Parentheses), Queue (Basic Queue Operations, Reverse First K, Interleave), and HashMap (all tests). Different loop counter indexes fail: __loopCount_0, __loopCount_9.
userStories.actualBehavior: Running tests with reference solutions containing loops throws errors: '__loopCount_0 is not defined' or '__loopCount_9 is not defined'. Tests fail immediately with this error.
userStories.expectedBehavior: Loop counter variables are properly declared and scoped. All reference solutions with loops execute successfully without variable scoping errors.
acceptanceCriteria: Stack easy test 'Balanced Parentheses Checker' reference solution runs without '__loopCount_0' error
Queue tests with loops execute without loop counter errors
HashMap tests execute without '__loopCount_9' error
All reference solutions with while, for, and do-while loops work correctly
Loop counter variables are declared at correct scope (function-level)
Counter declaration placement handles nested functions and arrow functions
SWC instrumentation properly handles all loop types

verify.command: agent-browser goto 'http://localhost:5173/?ds=stack&difficulty=easy' && agent-browser click @showSolutionButton && agent-browser click @runAllTestsButton && sleep 2 && agent-browser snapshot | grep '__loopCount'

agent-browser goto 'http://localhost:5173/?ds=queue&difficulty=easy' && agent-browser click @showSolutionButton && agent-browser click @runAllTestsButton && sleep 2 && agent-browser snapshot | grep '__loopCount'

agent-browser goto 'http://localhost:5173/?ds=hashMap&difficulty=easy' && agent-browser click @showSolutionButton && agent-browser click @runAllTestsButton && sleep 2 && agent-browser snapshot | grep '__loopCount'

verify.action: Verify test results show passed, not errors
verify.expected: Tests show 'Passed' status, not loop counter errors
No errors related to loop counter variables

technicalDetails.rootCause: Regex-based loop counter injection (lines 83-109) doesn't properly handle function scoping. The counter declaration is inserted before the loop keyword but may be in wrong scope when loop is inside a function.
technicalDetails.investigation: The regex `/(while\s*\(|for\s*\(|do\s*\{)/g` captures loop keywords but the replacement inserts counter declaration immediately before the keyword. This doesn't account for function boundaries.
potentialFix: Use SWC AST transformation instead of regex to properly detect function boundaries
Declare all loop counters at function scope at the beginning of each function
Track function depth during transformation and insert declarations at correct level
Consider using function-scoped counter with loop-specific suffixes

userStories.title: Array Reference Solutions Return Undefined - Missing Return Statements
userStories.description: All Array reference solutions fail tests because they return undefined instead of the expected sorted array. Easy, medium, and hard difficulty all affected. Tests show: 'Expected undefined to equal [1,2,5,8,9]' type errors.
userStories.actualBehavior: Array reference solutions execute but return undefined. Tests fail with: 'Sort Small Array: Expected undefined to equal [1,2,5,8,9]', 'Bubble Sort: Expected undefined to equal [11,12,22,25,34,64,90]', 'Quick Sort: Expected undefined to equal [10,30,40,50,70,80,90]'.
userStories.expectedBehavior: Array reference solutions return the sorted array. Tests pass with correct output matching expected values.
acceptanceCriteria: Array easy reference solution returns sorted array
Array medium reference solution returns bubble-sorted array
Array hard reference solution returns quick-sorted array
All Array tests pass when using reference solutions
No 'Expected undefined to equal' errors occur

verify.action: Load reference solution and run tests
verify.command: agent-browser click @showSolutionButton && sleep 1 && agent-browser click @runAllTestsButton && sleep 2

agent-browser goto 'http://localhost:5173/?ds=array&difficulty=medium' && agent-browser click @showSolutionButton && agent-browser click @runAllTestsButton && sleep 2 && agent-browser snapshot | grep 'Bubble Sort'

agent-browser goto 'http://localhost:5173/?ds=array&difficulty=hard' && agent-browser click @showSolutionButton && agent-browser click @runAllTestsButton && sleep 2 && agent-browser snapshot | grep 'Quick Sort'

technicalDetails.rootCause: Reference solutions in arrayTests.ts likely missing return statements or returning void
technicalDetails.investigation: Check referenceSolution fields for easy, medium, and hard tests - they probably mutate array in place but don't return it

userStories.title: LinkedList Reference Solutions Return Null - Incorrect Implementation
userStories.description: All LinkedList reference solutions fail tests because they return null instead of expected values. Easy test expects node value 30, medium expects reversed list [5,4,3,2,1], hard expects boolean false. All return null.
userStories.actualBehavior: LinkedList reference solutions return null. Tests fail with: 'Find Element: Expected null to be 30', 'Reverse Linked List: Expected null to equal [5,4,3,2,1]', 'Detect Cycle: Expected null to be false'.
userStories.expectedBehavior: LinkedList reference solutions return correct values: node value for find, reversed list array for reverse, boolean for cycle detection.
acceptanceCriteria: LinkedList easy reference solution returns correct node value
LinkedList medium reference solution returns reversed list as array
LinkedList hard reference solution returns boolean for cycle detection
All LinkedList tests pass when using reference solutions
No 'Expected null' errors occur

verify.command: agent-browser goto 'http://localhost:5173/?ds=linkedList&difficulty=easy' && agent-browser click @showSolutionButton && agent-browser click @runAllTestsButton && sleep 2

agent-browser goto 'http://localhost:5173/?ds=linkedList&difficulty=medium' && agent-browser click @showSolutionButton && agent-browser click @runAllTestsButton && sleep 2 && agent-browser snapshot | grep 'Reverse'

agent-browser goto 'http://localhost:5173/?ds=linkedList&difficulty=hard' && agent-browser click @showSolutionButton && agent-browser click @runAllTestsButton && sleep 2 && agent-browser snapshot | grep 'Cycle'

technicalDetails.rootCause: Reference solutions return null or don't return correct values
technicalDetails.investigation: Check referenceSolution implementations - they may have incorrect return statements or logic errors

userStories.title: Graph Reference Solutions Return Undefined - BFS and Dijkstra Issues
userStories.description: All Graph reference solutions fail tests because they return undefined instead of expected arrays. BFS should return vertex traversal array ['A','B','C','D','E'], Dijkstra should return path array.
userStories.actualBehavior: Graph reference solutions return undefined. Tests fail with: 'BFS Traversal: Expected undefined to equal ["A","B","C","D","E"]', 'Detect Cycle: Expected undefined to be true', 'Dijkstra: Expected undefined to equal ["A","C","B","D","E"]'.
userStories.expectedBehavior: Graph reference solutions return correct arrays/booleans. BFS returns traversal order, cycle detection returns boolean, Dijkstra returns shortest path.
acceptanceCriteria: Graph BFS test passes with correct vertex traversal array
Graph cycle detection returns boolean correctly
Graph Dijkstra's algorithm returns correct path array
TrackedGraph.bfs() method returns array in correct format
All Graph tests pass when using reference solutions
No 'Expected undefined' errors occur

verify.command: agent-browser goto 'http://localhost:5173/?ds=graph&difficulty=easy' && agent-browser click @showSolutionButton && agent-browser click @runAllTestsButton && sleep 2

agent-browser goto 'http://localhost:5173/?ds=graph&difficulty=medium' && agent-browser click @showSolutionButton && agent-browser click @runAllTestsButton && sleep 2 && agent-browser snapshot | grep 'Cycle'

agent-browser goto 'http://localhost:5173/?ds=graph&difficulty=hard' && agent-browser click @showSolutionButton && agent-browser click @runAllTestsButton && sleep 2 && agent-browser snapshot | grep 'Dijkstra'

verify.expected: BFS method is defined and returns array

technicalDetails.rootCause: Reference solution calls graph.bfs(start) but may not return the result, or TrackedGraph.bfs() doesn't return correctly
technicalDetails.investigation: Verify TrackedGraph has bfs() method that returns array. Check if reference solution returns the bfs() call result.

userStories.title: Stack and Queue Test Cases Use createTracked* Functions Not Available in Sandbox
userStories.description: Stack test cases reference createTrackedQueue function, and Queue test cases reference createTrackedStack function. These factory functions don't exist in the sandbox environment, causing 'is not defined' errors. The tests appear to be using the wrong tracked data structure constructors.
userStories.actualBehavior: Stack tests fail with 'createTrackedQueue is not defined'. Queue tests fail with 'createTrackedStack is not defined'. Multiple tests affected across both data structures.
userStories.expectedBehavior: Test cases use correct tracked data structure constructors available in sandbox. Stack tests use createTrackedStack or TrackedStack. Queue tests use createTrackedQueue or TrackedQueue.
acceptanceCriteria: Stack test cases only reference createTrackedStack or TrackedStack
Queue test cases only reference createTrackedQueue or TrackedQueue
All createTracked* factory functions are properly bundled in test runner
No 'is not defined' errors for tracked data structure constructors
Stack tests execute successfully without Queue-related errors
Queue tests execute successfully without Stack-related errors

verify.action: Test Stack - Check for Queue references
verify.command: agent-browser goto 'http://localhost:5173/?ds=stack&difficulty=easy' && agent-browser click @showSolutionButton && agent-browser click @runAllTestsButton && sleep 2 && agent-browser snapshot | grep 'createTrackedQueue'

verify.action: Test Queue - Check for Stack references
verify.command: agent-browser goto 'http://localhost:5173/?ds=queue&difficulty=easy' && agent-browser click @showSolutionButton && agent-browser click @runAllTestsButton && sleep 2 && agent-browser snapshot | grep 'createTrackedStack'

verify.expected: Both factory functions are imported and included in bundle
Stack tests use createTrackedStack, Queue tests use createTrackedQueue

technicalDetails.rootCause: Test cases in stackQueueTests.ts reference wrong tracked data structure constructors, OR factory functions aren't properly exported/bundled
technicalDetails.investigation: Check if test case setup code uses createTrackedQueue when it should use createTrackedStack and vice versa. Also verify testRunner.ts bundles these factory functions.

userStories.title: Stack Data Structure Shows Queue Test Cases (Test Case Mismatch)
userStories.description: When Stack data structure is selected, the test cases displayed include Queue-specific tests like 'Basic Queue Operations', 'Reverse First K Elements', and 'Interleave Two Halves of Queue'. These should only appear for Queue data structure.
userStories.actualBehavior: Selecting Stack shows 5 test cases: 'Balanced Parentheses Checker' (correct), 'Basic Queue Operations' (wrong), 'Reverse First K Elements' (wrong), 'Interleave Two Halves of Queue' (wrong), 'Min Stack with O(1) getMin' (correct).
userStories.expectedBehavior: Stack should only show Stack-specific test cases. Queue test cases should only appear when Queue data structure is selected.
acceptanceCriteria: Stack data structure shows only Stack test cases (no Queue tests)
Queue data structure shows only Queue test cases (no Stack tests)
Test case IDs correctly map to data structures (stack- prefix for stack tests, queue- prefix for queue tests)
Test case filtering in UI correctly separates Stack and Queue tests
Each data structure shows exactly 3 test cases (easy, medium, hard)

verify.action: Navigate to Stack and list test cases
Navigate to Queue and verify no Stack tests
verify.expected: No Stack-specific tests like 'Min Stack' appear
Test IDs properly use 'stack-' and 'queue-' prefixes

technicalDetails.rootCause: Test case filtering logic doesn't properly separate Stack and Queue tests, OR test IDs are incorrect/inconsistent
technicalDetails.investigation: Check how TestPanel filters tests by data structure type. Verify test case IDs in stackQueueTests.ts use correct prefixes.

userStories.title: HashMap Tests All Fail with Loop Counter Error - Same as BUG-002
userStories.description: All HashMap tests (easy, medium, hard) fail with '__loopCount_9 is not defined' error. This is manifestation of BUG-002 affecting HashMap specifically. Tests cannot execute because of instrumentation scoping issue.
userStories.actualBehavior: HashMap tests fail immediately with '__loopCount_9 is not defined'. All three difficulty levels affected: 'Basic Get/Set Operations', 'Collision Handling with Chaining', 'Character Frequency Counter'.
userStories.expectedBehavior: HashMap tests execute successfully without loop counter errors. Reference solutions with loops work correctly.
acceptanceCriteria: HashMap easy test runs without '__loopCount_9' error
HashMap medium test runs without loop counter errors
HashMap hard test runs without loop counter errors
All HashMap reference solutions execute successfully

verify.command: agent-browser goto 'http://localhost:5173/?ds=hashMap&difficulty=easy' && agent-browser click @showSolutionButton && agent-browser click @runAllTestsButton && sleep 2 && agent-browser snapshot | grep '__loopCount'

technicalDetails.rootCause: Same as BUG-002 - loop counter scoping issue in instrumenter.ts
technicalDetails.note: This will be resolved when BUG-002 is fixed. Tracking separately to verify HashMap specifically.

required: All critical user stories (BUG-001, BUG-002, BUG-003, BUG-004, BUG-005, BUG-006) must have passes=true
All high priority user stories (BUG-007, BUG-008) must have passes=true
npm run validate must exit with code 0
Application loads successfully at localhost:5173 for all data structures
All data structures load without console errors or blank screens
All reference solutions execute successfully across all data structures and difficulty levels
Agent-browser verification confirms all acceptance criteria met
recommended: Visualizations render correctly for all data structures
No D3/React conflicts or warnings in console
All test cases show correct pass/fail status (no 'undefined' or 'null' returns)

technicalNotes.testingApproach: Use agent-browser for automated UI verification. Each user story includes specific agent-browser commands for validation.
technicalNotes.testingMethodology: Systematic testing performed 2026-01-15 using agent-browser. Each data structure tested with Show Solution + Run All Tests workflow across all difficulty levels.
technicalNotes.devServer: npm run dev starts development server at http://localhost:5173
technicalNotes.validation: npm run validate runs all checks: lint + format + typecheck + test
technicalNotes.sandboxSecurity: User code runs in sandboxed iframe with allow-scripts only

bugDiscoverySession.coverage: All 7 data structures tested (Array, LinkedList, Stack, Queue, Binary Tree, Graph, HashMap)
bugDiscoverySession.testPattern: Navigate to ?ds={structure}&difficulty=easy → Click Show Solution → Click Run All Tests → Check results and console
bugsVerified: BUG-001: Binary Tree page completely blank with EditorPanel error
BUG-002: Loop counter scoping errors in Stack, Queue, HashMap
BUG-003: Array reference solutions return undefined
BUG-004: LinkedList reference solutions return null
BUG-005: Graph reference solutions return undefined
BUG-006: createTracked* functions not defined in sandbox
BUG-007: Stack shows Queue test cases
BUG-008: HashMap loop counter errors (duplicate of BUG-002)

criticalBlocking: BUG-001: Binary Tree completely broken - must fix first
BUG-002: Loop counter issue blocks Stack, Queue, HashMap - high impact
referenceImplementations: BUG-003, BUG-004, BUG-005: All reference solutions need return statement fixes
testInfrastructure: BUG-006: Sandbox bundle missing factory functions
fixPriority: 1. BUG-001 (Binary Tree template) - Blocks entire data structure
3. BUG-003, BUG-004, BUG-005 (Return statements) - All reference solutions fail

appliedPractices: Atomic user stories with clear acceptance criteria
Each bug is bite-sized and independently fixable
No human gut-checks - agent can verify itself
Progress tracking via passes: true/false field
Living TODO list (PRD is scope definition + progress tracker)
Session metadata tracking (iteration, date, tools used)
ralphWiggumBestPractices.iterationNotes: Start with BUG-001, mark passes: true when complete. Move to BUG-002, repeat. Ralph loop continues until all passes: true.
